title: From $1,000 to $100,000 in Five Years on an $83,000 Salary
subtitle: A step-by-step guide to growing your wealth through smart saving and investing.
content:
How I'd Go from $1,000 to $100,000 in Five Years

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. Now I make financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

Year 1

Contribute 6% to my 403B to capture the full 6% match. Add another $150 a month to my Roth IRA. Total saved: $11,760 with a 7% annual return. Year-end balance: $13,600.

Year 2

Same contributions, total saved: $11,760. Projected year-end balance: $27,000.

Year 3

I received a 4% raise at work, now earning $86,000. Bump my 403B contributions to 10%. Plus the 6% match, equals $13,811. Now contribute $6,500 to a Roth IRA. Total saved: $20,311. Balance at year's end: $50,000.

Year 4

Same contributions, total saved: $20,311. Ending balance: About $75,000.

Year 5

Another 4% raise brings my earnings to $89,000. Increase my 403B contributions to 12% plus the 6% match. That's $5,386. Max out my Roth IRA with $7,000 in 2025. Total saved: $23,159. Final balance: Just over $100,000.

Summary

Did I inherit wealth? No. Did I hit it big on Donkey Coin? No. Did I automate my contributions, get my full employer match, increase my contributions as my paycheck increased, and take advantage of low-cost funds in my 403B and my Roth IRA? Yes. And thatâ€™s how I got from $1,000 to $100,000 in five years on the National Median Household Income.

If any of this is helpful, sign up for my free weekly newsletter by clicking the link in my bio. Each week, I'll send you over another money playbook that actually works.
